qas.question: What language did Middle Dutch come from?
What year do some researchers say marked the point when Old Dutch morphed?
Rather than a single language, what group sharing origins in Old Dutch does the term "Middle Dutch" refer to?
Would a text written in Middle Dutch be readable or unintelligible for a Dutch speaker today?

context: <a0_0>Old Dutch<a0_0/> naturally evolved into Middle Dutch. The year <a1_0>1150<a1_0/> is often cited as the time of the discontinuity, but it actually marks a time of profuse Dutch writing and during this period a rich Medieval Dutch literature developed. There was at that time no overarching standard language; Middle Dutch is rather a collective name for a number of <a2_0>closely related dialects<a2_0/> whose ancestor was Old Dutch. But they were all mutually intelligible. In fact, since Dutch is a rather conservative language, the various literary works of that time today are often very <a3_0>readable<a3_0/> for modern-day speakers.
